Dimension.name: dimension
doc: I am a /unit of measurement/!
I can be any standardized units, like ⧼1m⧽, ⧼10s⧽, ⧼100g⧽, or any other scientific unit. I'm happy to be any unit want to make up too, like ⧼17apple⧽.
I can be combined with ⧼/⧽ to make ratio units like ⧼17apple/day⧽ and with ⧼^⧽ to make exponentional units like ⧼9.8m/s^2⧽
I must always come after a @Measurement. If I don't, I might be mistaken for @Reference, which would be quite embarassing!
I'm pretty good at finding inconsistencies between units too. For example, ⧼1cat + 1dog⧽ doesn't make any sense!
If you ever want to convert between different values of units, go talk to @Convert.

Doc.name: documentation
doc: I describe the purpose of code.
I can go before any expression:
⧼1 - `Is this really supposed to be 7?`7⧽
For example, you can place me before @Bind:

⧼`I measure how tall someone is`
height: 5m⧽
Or before a @FunctionDefinition:

⧼`I add two numbers`
ƒ sum(a•# b•#) a + b⧽
Or before a @StructureDefinition:

⧼`I remember people's name and favorite fruit`
•Person(name•'' fruit•'')⧽
You can also place me at the very beginning of @Program to say what the whole performance is about

⧼`This program says hello`

'hello!'⧽
You can give me a @Language to help others know what language I'm written in:

⧼`I'm an English doc`/en
duration: 5s⧽
Did you know you can make a list of me? Go talk to @Docs.

Docs.name: documentation list
doc: I'm a list of @Doc, useful when you have multiple translations of @Doc in different languages.
You don't have to do anything special to make a list. Just put a bunch of @Doc next to each other, like this:

⧼`Hello`/en
`Hola`/es
greeting: '…'⧽

KeyValue.name: key/value pair
doc: I'm a mapping from a *key* to a *value*, always in a @Map.
You can map any kind of value to any other. For example, here's a mappning of numbers:
Or a mapping from text to numbers:

Language.name: language
doc: I'm a language tag and I work with @Name and @Doc!
I'm really good at making it *crystal clear* what lanugage something is written in.
That's what I do. Just a little slash, and a couple letters, and no one will ever be confused about what language some text is in.
For example, let's say you wanted to say my $name, but make it clear I'm in English:
⧼"Language"/en⧽
Or, suppose you wanted to do this for a @Name.
⧼sound/en: 'meow'⧽
Or even @Doc!

⧼`Onomatopoeia`/en
sound/en: "meow"⧽
There are many <2-letter language codes@https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ISO_639-1_codes> that I understand. If you don't use one of those, I'll let you know.

conflict.MissingLanguage: I'm missing a language. Can you add one?

Name.name: name
doc: I identify a value, and am a helpful way of giving a shorthand label to something that was hard to evaluate, or that you don't want to have to evaluate over and over.
@Bind gives me my name like this:
I only ever represent one value, and once I have it, I can't change. For example, if you tried to do this with @Bind, we would complain.

⧼hi: 5
hi: 3⧽
All you have to do to get my value is have @Reference or @PropertyReference use name. Here, @Bind names me, then @Reference get the value I was given.

⧼hi: 5
hi⧽
Because @Bind can show up in so many places, I can show up in many places. I was in a @Block above, but I can be in a @FunctionDefinition. Here I am naming a message temporarily:
⧼ƒ say(message•'') message⧽
I get defined inside @FunctionDefinition, and then as soon as the function is done evaluating, I go away.
You can use @Language to indicate what language my name is in. This is helpful when sharing your performance with others, in case they want to read your program.

Names.name: name list
doc: I'm a list of @Name, useful when you want to give a value multiple names, often with different @Language.
Names are separated by ⧼,⧽ symbols. For example, here's @Bind giving a value multiple @Name
⧼hi/en,hello/en,hola/es: 'welcome'⧽

conflict.InvalidRow: $? I'm missing one or more columns

MissingCell.secondary: $? I'm required, but $2 didn't provide it

conflict.UnknownColumn: $? I don't know a column by this name

Token.name: token
doc: How did you find me?
I am the smallest possible part of a performance. I am the substrate from which all characters in the Verse are made. I am the atomic particle of our choreography.

TypeInputs.name: type inputs
TypeInputs.doc: $? a list of types given to a @FunctionDefinition or @StructureDefinition

TypeVariable.name: type variable
TypeVariable.doc: $? a placeholder for a type used in a @FunctionDefinition or @StructureDefinition

DuplicateTypeVariable.primary: I have the same name as $1
DuplicateTypeVariable.secondary: I have the same name as $1

Paragraph.name: paragraph
doc: I'm a series of @Words, @ConceptLink, @WebLink, and @Example, separated by a blank line, and inside @Doc.
All you need to do to write me is write a bunch of words in a @Doc:
⧼`I am a paragraph in a doc.`'one paragraph'⧽
If you want multiple paragraphs, just put in blank lines.

⧼`Paragraph 1.

Paragraph 2.

Paragraph 3.`'three paragraphs'⧽

WebLink.name: link
doc: I am a link to something on the internet. I just need a description and a URL:

⧼`I am a <link@https://wordplay.dev> in a doc`
'link example'⧽
If anyone selects me, I'll open a new window to the URL.

ConceptLink.name: concept
doc: I'm a link to Verse character. I'm helpful when you want to write a @Doc and refer to one of us.
For example, say you wanted to talk about @Evaluate, and how awesome they are. You could write:

⧼`You know, @Evaluate is pretty awesome.`
'look, a concept link!'⧽
When the @Doc you wrote appears here, it'll show a link to the concept.

Words.name: words
doc: I'm any words you like in a @Doc. For example:

⧼`May the Force be with you.`
'just some words!'⧽
Sometimes though, you might want to use the special characters that @Doc uses /as/ words. For example:

⧼`My friends use @@, //, **, ||, and other symbols.`
'using special characters!'⧽
If you just repeat those special characters, you'll get the character instead of their special meaning.

Example.name: example
doc: I'm an example performance, helpful for writing @Doc that explains how to use something!
⧼`Here's an example of adding: ⧼1 + 1⧽`'example code'⧽
If you put me in a paragraph all alone, I'll show up in a fancy box and show the result of evaluating me.

⧼`Here's an example of adding:

⧼1 + 1⧽`⧽

BinaryOperation.name: binary operation
doc: Sometimes when I'm evaluating a @FunctionDefinition with just one value on the left and one value on the right, I like to use this form, instead of @Evaluate.
⧼1 + 1⧽ is just so much simpler than ⧼1.+(1)⧽ or ⧼1.add(1)⧽.
It makes everything a bit tidier, even though its basically the same thing.

conflict.OrderOfOperations: I'll evalute left to right, unlike math; do you want to use @Block to specify a different order?

Bind.name: bind
doc: Hello!
I love names.
I name things.
Can I name you?
Do you have something I can name?
Give me an expression and I'll name it!
I name inputs to @FunctionDefinition and @StructureDefinition, I name values in @Block. I name everything!
Why name something?
Well, some of us are fine without a name because we collaborate so closely.
But sometimes its helpful to give us names so you can refer to us by name instead.
Be careful with names though: once I name a value, it will *always* have that value.
And also don't like it when multiple things have the same name.
That just gets confusing.
One name, one value!
Oh, but did you know you can have one value *many names*?
I'm s excited to tell you about this!
One value, many names. For example:
⧼joe,tess,amy: 5⧽
See what I did there?
One value, three names.
You can refer to that five by *any* of those names.
This is especially when you want to give names in many languages:
⧼joe/en,aimee/fr,明/zh: 5⧽
See what I did *there*?
Three names for one value, just in different languages!
Okay, I have one last secret.
Did you know that you can tell me what kind of value a name should have, and if it doesn't have it, I will tell you?
Like this:
⧼bignumber•#: "one zillion"⧽
See, I said (bignumber) should be a number, but it's text, and those aren't compatible and so BOOM!
I'll let you know if they disagree.
Sometimes you might *have* to tell me what kind of data something else because I can't figure it out myself.
Bind.start: Let's see what value we get from $1
Bind.finish: Oh nice, I got $1! Let's name it $2

DuplicateName.primary: Someone has my name, so I can't have this name.

DuplicateShare.primary: I have the same name as $1, which makes what is shared ambiguous
DuplicateShare.secondary: I have has the same name as $1

IncompatibleBind.primary: I'm supposed to be $1, but I'm $2
IncompatibleBind.secondary: Hey, I got a $2 instead of a $1

conflict.MisplacedShare: I can only be at the top level of a $program, not inside anything.
conflict.MissingShareLanguages: If you want to share, say what language this is in, so others can find it if they know your language.
conflict.RequiredAfterOptional: required inputs can't come after optional ones
conflict.UnexpectedEtc: only functions can have variable length inputs
conflict.UnusedBind: Hey, can I help? No one is saying my name :(

Block.name: block
doc: Have you met my friend @Bind?
I think you'd know if you had.
Sometimes they are so annoying.
They're always like 'name this', 'name that'
We work together a lot, because my job is to make a
space to temporarily name complicated things.
@Bind names them, and I keep track of all the names
and evaluate to whatever value was last.
And that makes your job as director easier, right?
So you can calculate things?
Well @Bind does *not* make my job easier!
This happened last week:
@Bind just went on and on and on, spelling out the whole alphabet and numbering
them and I was just like "*Can you just give me 26? You didn't even use any of those names. I could have just passed on 26 and we would have been done.*"
Why do you have to name them all?
This is is why I like working with @FunctionDefinition.
They put @Bind up there with all the @Name
I can just focus on my business.
Of course, @Bind always shows up there too.
Okay, I think I'm done venting.
I really do like @Bind.
They are my friend.
Their love of names is cute sometimes.
Sometimes I just need some quiet.
Block.start: Here we go with @Bind again, getting all excited about naming things
Block.finish: Finally done. The last thing I got was $1

conflict.ExpectedEndingExpression: I need at least one expression.

IgnoredExpression.primary: I'm going to use this value and ignore other ones above.
IgnoredExpression.secondary: Why are you ignoring me, I want to help!

BooleanLiteral.name: boolean
doc: We are ⧼⊤⧽ and ⧼⊥⧽.
We represent true and false.
True is not false and false is not true.
Use our functions to reason about truth.
But leave ambiguity out of it.

Borrow.name: borrow
Borrow.doc: $?Use a binding from another $source or performance.

conflict.UnknownBorrow: I don't know a $souce by this name
conflict.BorrowCycle: this depends on $1, which depends on this $source, so the $program can't be evaluated

Changed.name: changed
Changed.doc: $?true if a stream caused a $program to re-evaluate
Changed.start: check if $1 caused this $program to reevaluate
Changed.keep: keeping the stream instead of getting its latest value

Conditional.name: conditional
doc: Did you ever think about how we decide?
I think about that a lot.
So many decisions in life can be so complicated.
Sometimes I feel a lot of pressure to decide, since I'm the only one in this world who gets to decide.
I get overwhelmed, and so I've tried to simplify things.
@BooleanLiteral helps see that I could reduce everything to just two options: ⧼⊤⧽ and ⧼⊥⧽.
If it's ⧼⊤⧽, then I evaluate my *yes* code. If it's ⧼⊥⧽, then I evaluate my *no* code.
I know that decisions are rarely this simple, but breaking down the world into these two options makes things easier for me.
It's my little way of keeping things organized, even in the face of so much complexity.
Yes, no, if, else, this, that.
Hm, I'm starting to sound like @BooleanLiteral...
Conditional.else: $1 ?? [jumping over code | not jumping over code]

ExpectedBooleanCondition.primary: I can't choose between yes and no with a $1. Can you give me a @TextType?
ExpectedBooleanCondition.secondary: I wish I evaluated to a @TextType, but I'm a $1

ConversionDefinition.name: conversion
ConversionDefinition.doc: $?define a conversion from one value type to another

conflict.MisplacedConversion: I'm not allowed here, only in a $structure.

Convert.name: convert
doc: Yo. I turn values from one type to another. Check it out:
⧼"hello" → []⧽
You can even chain these together:
Values have a set of @ConversionDefinition that are predefined, but if you make a @StructureDefinition for a new type of value, you can define your own.
Convert.start: let's get the value to convert from $1

conflict.UnknownConversion: I couldn'tn find a way to make $1 into a $2

Evaluate.name: evaluate
doc: Hi. Are you looking for me? I evaluate @FunctionDefinition.
For example, if you had this function, I could evaluate it like this:
⧼ƒ greeting(message•"")
"Hello " + message
greeting('kitty')⧽
Your function can come from anywhere. For example, @TextLiteral has functions. Like this:
⧼'kitty'.length()⧽
If a function has a single symbol name, you can work with @BinaryOperation.
⧼'kitty' ⊆ 'itty'⧽
That does the same thing as :
⧼'kitty'.⊆('itty')⧽

IncompatibleInput.primary: I'm supposed to be a $1, but I'm a $2
IncompatibleInput.secondary: Umm, I got a $2 instead of a $1

UnexpectedTypeInput.primary: I wasn't expecting this type input
UnexpectedTypeInput.secondary: Am I supposed to be here?

conflict.MisplacedInput: I think this input is misplaced. Check the order?

MissingInput.primary: I need $1, can you add one?
MissingInput.secondary: This input is required, but $2 did not provide it

conflict.NotInstantiable: cannot make this $structure because it refers to an interface

UnexpectedInput.secondary: Am I supposed to be here?

UnknownInput.primary: I don't know of an input by this name
UnknownInput.secondary: I don't think I belong here

conflict.InputListMustBeLast: list of inputs must be last

exception.FunctionException: Oops, I don't know how to $1

ExpressionPlaceholder.name: placeholder
doc: I'm supposed to be an *expression*, but I really don't know how to do anything.
Directors usually use me to temporarily hold some space in a performance while they figure out what they want to do.
Like, if we were adding some numbers, I might take the place of a number (1 + _), or if someone was evaluating a function with @Evaluate, I might stand in for the function (_(1 2 3)).
But as soon as someone decides what to replace me with, I'm out.
Which is good, because I'm terrified of being on stage, let alone in @Program!
ExpressionPlaceholder.start: Stop the performance, I don't know what to do!

conflict.Placeholder: Can someone take my place? I don't know what to do.

exception.UnimplementedException: I don't know what to do here!!

FunctionDefinition.name: function
FunctionDefinition.doc: $?define a function that maps input values to an output value

HOF.name: higher order function
HOF.next: apply the function to the next item

conflict.ImpossibleType: this can never be this type

ListLiteral.name: list
doc: I'm a list of expressions! You can put anything in me: @BooleanLiteral, @MeasurementLiteral, @TextLiteral, @NoneLiteral, even other @ListLiteral, @SetLiteral, @MapLiteral, and more.
What makes me special is that I keep things in order and I number everything from 1 to however many items are in me.
For example, the three words in this list are numbered 1, 2, and 3.
⧼['apple' 'banana' 'mango']⧽
You can get values that I'm storing by their number.
For example, the second value in this list is ⧼['banana']⧽
⧼['apple' 'banana' 'mango'][2]⧽

MapLiteral.name: map
doc: I'm a mapping from keys to values.
My keys can be any kind of value, and my values can be any kind of value.
I work with @Bind to connect values.
Some people like to think of my like an index, or a dictionary, where you give me something, and I give you what it's mapped to.
For example, here's a mapping from numbers to their number words:
⧼{1: 'one' 2: 'two' 3: 'three'}⧽
If you wanted to check what something is mapped to, just give me the key and I'll give you the value:
If I don't have it, I'll give you @NoneLiteral.
I have many, many @FunctionDefinition for adding things to a mapping, removing things, getting the set of keys or values, and more.
MapLiteral.start: evaluate each key and value first

NotAKeyValue.primary: I'm a map, so everything you give me has to be in pairs.
NotAKeyValue.secondary: Oops, I'm in a map without a partner!

MeasurementLiteral.name: number
doc: I can be any number you like and even a number with units, if you like.
That's basically an infinite number of numbers.
And an infinite number of units!
And an infinite number of number/unit pairs…
Here are my top 5:
⧼1story⧽
⧼πpie⧽
⧼∞rock⧽
⧼1000000dollar⧽
Just know that if you try to use my @FunctionDefinition on numbers with different units, I won't know what to do.
If they don't match, that might be a sign that there's something wrong with your performance.

conflict.NotANumber: I'm not formatted correctly to be a number

NoneLiteral.name: none
doc: /Hi, @FunctionDefinition here. @NoneLiteral doesn't like to say much, so I'll translate./
@NoneLiteral represents the absence of anything.
It's a way of saying "There is no value".
You'll find it in many @FunctionDefinition that have optional inputs, such as @Phrase.
It's only equal to itself.

Program.name: program
doc: You know how @Block evaluates a list of expressions, and evaluates to the last one in its list?
I'm the same, but rather than giving my value to whatever expression I'm in, I put the value on stage.
The value can be anything: a @MeasurementLiteral, @TextLiteral, or @BooleanLiteral, a @ListLiteral, @SetLiteral, @MapLiteral, or even something more complex, like a @Phrase, @Group, or @Stage.
If you don't give me a value to show on stage, I'll probably ask you for one.
Program.unevaluated: the selected node did not evaluate
Program.start: $1 ?? [ stream changed, reevaluating | evaluating for the first time ]

exception.BlankException: I'm so excited to put on a show with you! Where should we start?
exception.EvaluationLimitException: I evaluated too many functions, especially $1
exception.StepLimitException: I evaluated too many steps in this function
exception.ValueException: Oh no! I expected a value, but I didn't get one

PropertyBind.name: refine
PropertyBind.finish: I created a new $structure $1 set to $2

Reaction.name: reaction
Reaction.doc: A reaction to a stream change.
Reaction.start: first check if the stream has changed

conflict.UnknownName: I don't know what I refer to  in $2 ?? [$2|this @Block]
conflict.ReferenceCycle: $1 depends on itself, so there's no way to evaluate it.
conflict.UnexpectedTypeVariable: type inputs not allowed on type variables

exception.NameException: I feel... unbound, with no value. Am I supposed to have a value in $1 ?? [ $1 | this @Block ]?

Select.name: select
Select.finish: evaluated to a new table with the selected rows, $1

conflict.ExpectedSelectName: I need at least one column name.

SetLiteral.name: set
doc: I'm a set. That means I can contain any number of values, including zero values. You can make me like this:
I'm really good if you want to keep a collection of things without duplicates.
That means I only contain one of each value. If you give me values I already have, I'll ignore the extras.
For example, this set has many duplicates:
I evaluate it to just ⧼{1 2 3}⧽.
If you want to see if I have a value, you can check like this:
⧼mysterySet{3}⧽
I also have so many @FunctionDefinition to add, remove, combine, analyze, and convert my collection of values.
You should be able to find whatever you need amo

StructureDefinition.name: structure
StructureDefinition.doc: $?define a structure that stores values and functions on those values.

conflict.DisallowedInputs: I can't have inputs because one of or more of my functions isn't implemented
conflict.IncompleteImplementation: My functions either need to all be implemented, or none be implemented. No messy mixtures!
conflict.NotAnInterface: I am not an interface; a $structure can only implement interfaces, not other structures

Template.name: text template
doc: I can be placed inside @TextLiteral to combine text and other values into a larger text value.
For instance, consider this:
⧼"Here are some sums \1 + 2\, \2 + 3\, \3 + 4\"⧽
See how elegantly I just evaluated those sums, and placed them inside the @TextLiteral?
You can use me instead of adding @TextType together.
Template.start: let us evaluate each expression in the text

TextLiteral.name: text
doc: I can be any text you like, and use any of these text symbols: ⧼""⧽, ⧼“”⧽, ⧼„“⧽, ⧼''⧽, ⧼‘’⧽, ⧼‹›⧽, ⧼«»⧽, ⧼「」⧽, or ⧼『'⧽.
Just remember to close me if you open me, and use the matching symbol.
Otherwise I won't know that you're done with your words.

conflict.MisplacedThis: I'm only allowed in a $structure, $conversion, or $reaction.

UnaryOperation.name: unary operation
doc: Did you know that when I'm evaluating a @FunctionDefinition with just one value, and the name of the @FunctionDefinition is just a single symbol, you can put the name before the input?
Like, ⧼-(1 + 1)⧽ or ⧼~⊥⧽, for example. Those are much easier to read than ⧼(1 + 1).negate()⧽ or ⧼⊥.not()⧽.
You don't have to write me that way, but it might be easier overall.
There's only one rule: you can't put any space between the name and the value. Otherwise you might be making a @Reference or @BinaryOperation.

UnparsableExpression.name: unparsable
doc: (Hi @FunctionDefinition here. I'm translating for @UnparsableExpression, since they're often hard to interpret.)
Not every expression has meaning on stage.
In fact, there are all kinds of things you can say that don't make any sense at all.
When you do, I show up. I'll try to guess what you might have meant, but it's up to you to fix it.
You are the director after all, so only you know what you might have meant!

conflict.UnparsableConflict: (@FunctionDefinition here, @UnparsableExpression doesn't know what kind of $1 ?? [ expression | type ] this is)

Update.name: update rows
Update.finish: evaluated to a new table with revised rows, $1

conflict.ExpectedUpdateBind: I need a value for every column

IncompatibleCellType.primary: I needed a $1, but got a $2

ConversionType.name: conversion
ConversionType.doc: a type of function that converts values of one type to another

conflict.UnknownTypeName: type names can only refer to structures or type variables, but this refers to a $1

UnknownNameType.name: unknown name
UnknownNameType.description: $1 ?? [$1 isn't defined | a name wasn't given]

doc: We are single true or false value.
We are the simplest value type, since we can only be one of two values, (⊤) and (⊥).
name: Boolean

doc: I am nothing
I am special because I am only equal to me.
I can only ever be me and only ever want to be me!
name: ø
None

doc: We are any words imaginable.
We can represent ideas, stories, words, and more, and even represent other types of values, but as text.
name: Text

doc: We are any number imaginable, even with units.
We can be integers, real numbers, negative, positive, fractional, decimal. We can be Arabic numbers (123), Roman numerals (ⅩⅩⅩⅠⅩ), Japanese numerals (二十), and more.
name: Measurement

doc: I take two @Measurement with the same @Unit and add them together, creating a new @MeasurementType of the same @Unit.
For example:
⧼3cat + 5cat⧽
If the units don't match, I halt the show.
⧼3cat + 5dog⧽
We group values in sequence.
Keeping this in order is our mission; but we can only do that if we stay together ([]).
name: List

doc: We group unique values in no particular order.
We don't like it when there's more than one value of a particular kind! Everything must be unique.
name: Set

doc: We map one set of values to another set of values.
Everything inside us must be connected, but to only one thing.
name: Map

doc: /@FunctionDefinition here. I'll explain @Time, since it doesn't speak./
Time is a stream that ticks at a certain frequency.
Each time it does, @Program reevaluates with the new time value.
For example:
⧼Time()⧽
If you provide time a @Time/frequency, it will tick at that rate. For example:
⧼Time(1000ms)⧽
However, there are limits to how small it can be, since @Program needs time to evaluate before they can respond to the next tick.
The smallest is probably around ⧼20ms⧽.

frequency.doc: This is the frequency with which time should tick. It defaults to ⧼33ms⧽, which is about 30 times per second.

tooltip.pause: evaluate the $program one step at a time
tooltip.reset: restart the evaluation of the performance from the beginning.
tooltip.fullscreen: fill the browser with this window
tooltip.dark: toggle dark mode on, off, and default

labels.nodoc: Who am I? What am I? What is my purpose?

feedback.unknownProject: There's no performance with this ID.

login.prompt: Log in to access your performances.
login.anonymousPrompt: Your performances are saved on this device. Create an account to save them online.
login.enterEmail: It looks like you're logging in on a different device. Can you enter your email again?
login.sent: Check your email for a link.

error.tutorial: We weren't able to find a tutorial for this language.
